column1: Kaposi sarcoma is a cancerous tumor of the connective tissue, and is often associated with AIDS.
Before the AIDS epidemic, Kaposi sarcoma was seen mainly in elderly Italian and Jewish men, and rarely, in elderly women.
People who have kidney or other organ transplants are also at risk for Kaposi sarcoma.
The tumors (lesions) most often appear as bluish-red or purple bumps on the skin.
Lesions in the lungs can cause bloody sputum or shortness of breath.
